Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Opportunities for Undergraduates in the Heliophysics Science Division at the NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will provide research opportunities in solar and heliospheric physics topics for undergraduate students, in collaboration with the Heliophysics Science Division of the Science and Exploration Directorate at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center (NASA/GSFC). This undergraduate experience will allow students to interact with active researchers in a stimulating multidisciplinary environment at a major NASA laboratory, under the guidance of scientists who are committed to the education and mentoring of women, underrepresented minorities, and students with disabilities. This synergistic program will expose students to a wide range of research projects in solar and space physics and will leverage a NASA-funded program for undergraduate research at NASA/GSFC. Over the last nineteen years, this REU site at Catholic University of America has sponsored over 280 students, with about half that number being supported by NSF funding.

The students participating in this program will become the future engineers, scientists, and STEM teachers of our nation. Even those students who choose careers not related to STEM disciplines will greatly benefit from the program by gaining a deeper understanding of the importance of science and technology in our society, especially in the context of space physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have provided exceptional research opportunities for undergraduate students in one of the world's premier research centers (The Heliospheric Science Division (HSD) at NASA's Goddard Space flight Center). dedicated to the study of the Sun, its heliosphere, and space weather. Specifically, The NSF/REU program directly supported 34 young, talented undergraduates, with a large fraction being women and under-represented minorites. These young persons gained scientific and engineering training in the HSD.  Many of these were offered additional in-depth training at NASA beyond their initial NSF/REU expereince. Of these, where data were availalble, all either entered into careers in the core STEM disciplines, or have entered graduate school. The training that these indivuals have received should make them valuable contibutors in the Nation's workforce, which is strongly in need of professionals trained in the STEM disciplines.

 Our previous experience,over 25 years, shows that many young people often take time off from their educational training before entering a graduate program. The longerterm extended experiences at NASA/GSFC, beyond that provided by the NSF/REU internships, offered in-depth training for the participants, which is often not realized in other programs. These extended opportunities prove critical to retaining and developing the skills of these students, who will become scientists, engineers, teachers, and other trained professional in the STEM workforce. 

This program has been joinlty supported by NSF/REU and NASA/GSFC funds.
